trans-unit.source: This class can be used for issuing the symmetric key based token.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SymmetricProofDescriptor"></xref> class with the specified encrypting credentials.
Use this constructor if you want the STS to use the specified <xref:System.IdentityModel.Tokens.EncryptingCredentials>.
The <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.EncryptingCredentials"></xref> to be used.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SymmetricProofDescriptor"></xref> class with the specified key material.
Use this constructor if you want the STS to use the specified key bytes.
This happens when client sends the entropy, and the STS would just use that as the key for the issued token.
The symmetric key that is used inside the issued token.
The key encrypting credentials for the relying party.
key is `null`.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SymmetricProofDescriptor"></xref> class with an auto-generated key.
Use this constructor if you want the STS to auto-generate the key using a random number generator and send it in the proof token as a binary secret.
The size of the symmetric key.
The key encrypting credentials for the target of the request.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SymmetricProofDescriptor"></xref> class with an auto-generated key.
Use this constructor if you want the STS to auto-generate the key and send it in the proof token as encrypted key.
Two cases can be covered by using this constructor:
The client sends the entropy, but the server rejects it.
The client does not send the entropy, so the server's entropy is used.
The size of the symmetric key.
The key encrypting credentials for the target of the request.
The key encrypting credentials for the requestor.
keySizeInBits is less than or equal to zero.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SymmetricProofDescriptor"></xref> class to use for sending combined entropy.
Use this constructor if you want to send a combined entropy.
The size of the symmetric key.
The key encrypting credentials for the target of the request.
The encrypting credentials for the requestor used to encrypt the entropy or the proof token.
The requestor's entropy.
sourceEntropy is `null` or an empty array.
keySize is less than zero.
Use this constructor to have the STS autogenerate a key and send it in the proof token as encrypted key.
Two cases are covered here 1.
client sends the entropy, but server rejects it 2.
client did not send a entropy, so just use server's entropy
If `encryptWith` is a DES algorithm, the key is guaranteed not to be a weak DES key.
Use this constructor if you want the STS to auto-generate the key and send it in the proof token as encrypted key.
Two cases can be covered by using this constructor:
The client sends the entropy, but the server rejects it.
The client does not send the entropy, so the server's entropy is used.
The size of the symmetric key.
The key encrypting credentials for the relying party.
The key encrypting credentials for the requestor.
The algorithm (URI) specified in the `<EncryptWith>` element of the RST.
keySizeInBits is less than or equal to zero.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SymmetricProofDescriptor"></xref> class to use for sending combined entropy.
Use this constructor to send combined entropy.
The size of the symmetric key.
The encrypting credentials for the relying party used to encrypt the key in the SecurityKeyIdentifier property.
The encrypting credentials for the requestor used to encrypt the entropy or the proof token.
The requestor's entropy.
The URI of the algorithm to use to encrypt the proof key.
keySizeInBits is less than or equal to zero.
sourceEntropy is `null` or an empty array.
Modifies the specified RSTR based on the settings in this proof descriptor.
Sets the appropriate artifacts, such as the requested proof token, inside the RSTR based on what is inside the proof descriptor instance.
The RSTR to which to apply the proof descriptor.
response is `null`.
Gets the key material.
A byte array that contains the key material.
Gets the source entropy in plain bytes.
A byte array that contains the source entropy.
Gets the target entropy in plain bytes
A byte array that contains the target entropy.
Gets the key identifier that can be used inside the issued token to define the key.
It is usually the binary secret or the encrypted key;
The key identifier.
Gets the requestor's encrypting credentials, which may be used to encrypt the requested proof token or the entropy in the response.
The requestorâ€™s encrypting credentials.
Gets the relying party encrypting credentials, which may be used to encrypt the requested security token in the response.
The relying party encrypting credentials.
